author: LAPhill
content:
Just wrapped on a score and my self-imposed rule was "no orchestra." Because we weren't going to have the budget for a live one and I'm 100% in the camp of making your limitations sound like intentional choices. 

There were so many times I wanted to reach for the orchestral samples to sell an emotional moment, or fill out a part. Not letting myself do that forced me to come up with other solutions, and the results are so much more interesting than some Spitfire samples in the background.

author: LAPhill
content:
By far, the most important element in realistic orchestral sound is in the programming. You need a controller where you can automate cc1 and cc11 (modulation and expression). Instruments, especially strings, are constantly changing their volumes. Particularly on entrances and phrase-ends. If you don't have a controller for this, you can draw it all in, but that gets really tedious.

If you get that figured out, I can almost guarantee that just about any library out there will get you good results. So then it's just a matter of what sound do you gravitate towards, how elaborate of a feature set do you need, etc. Legatos are overrated and I'd take no legato over a poorly programmed one any day.

If you want a full orchestra, not just strings, I'd check out some of the all-in-one offerings from Spitfire (Albion, BBC Orchestra, or Abbey Road), East West, Orchestral Tools (Inspire), or VSL (Prime). They all will have several different articulations, a decent amount of dynamic layers, and a full set of orchestral instruments. Have a listen to them and see what sounds grab you. Spitfire and Orchestral Tools have a more prominent room sound baked in, but they all do to some extent. So be aware that, whichever library you choose, there's a certain amount of "reverb" (which is actually just the hall they're recorded in) that you will never be able to turn off.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I couldn't speak to the current state of samplers, but I've always wished that someone would build a bold sampler that wasn't afraid to be really wacky and full of unique characteristics. For starters:

1. Include a radio tuner. 
2. Maybe some really nice - but heavily colored - preamps.
3. Include all kinds of weird peripheral sensors like devices that pick up EMF signals or a few contact mics. Include a suite of effect plugins that are specially geared towards these input methods.
4. Super-intuitive resampling, time-stretching, and pitch-shifting features.
5. An algorithm that analyzes the dominant pitch of a loop and auto-maps it to a keyboard. It should be capable of re-orienting itself as the dominant pitch of a loop is adjusted.
6. Tracker-style sequencing capabilities.
7. An OTT-style compressor. Maybe something really trashy and blown-out like Devil-Loc or Vulf Compressor. Something that really messes with the proportions of a sample.
8. Easy and flexible integration of feedback loops.
9. Intuitive integration of polyrhythmic looping or sequencing.
10. A feature for easy implementation of Steve Reich 'It's Gonna Rain' style tape loop phasing.
11. Auto-bpm detection keyed off of designated inputs (ala Ableton).
12. Automated master tempo effects.

I could go on.

The law says "any use" needs to be cleared. One of the major legal cases even specified no minimum length.

That being said, nearly all drum one shots are commonly uncleared. There are some other exceptions that would fall under being a generic sound of some sort.

The short answer is, if someone can recognize it from their original recording, you can be sued. 

Most people don't bother trying to clear things because they don't have budget. Usually nothing ever happens because most songs don't get big enough for the copyright owner to care. Then again, I heard Gotye had to give away 80% of Somebody That I Used To Know because of the two chord uncleared bossa nova guitar lick.

author: sukhuno
content: So basically what i did was i set up an ableton multisampler with all of my favourite linn drum sounds + some others that i liked (did this for snares and kicks) - so about 127 each. then i made 4 versions of that in an instrument rack and split them using multiband to only certain freq ranges (low, low mid, mid, high) - i think i used shaperbox for this. then i used an ableton random midi effect so it would trigger random samples in each of the 4 instrument racks... so you create a new sound from the seed sounds you choose. you get sounds that are in the linn drum ballpark but just a little different - which is the cool thing. https://we.tl/t-MxppdXPQlf here are some of the ones i liked (kicks, pitched snare, snares) that i made using this method

author: austenballard
content:
Test is done. Tl;dr they don't null completely. They don't even detect the same audio the same.

**INTRODUCTION**
Beckley, et al. (2023) reported differences in tuning results between the plugin and standalone versions of Melodyne. This investigator undertook a test of Melodyne plugin, ARA and standalone versions to determine whether the resulting tuned audio would null.

**METHODS**

All testing was performed at a sample rate of 48kHz and with .wav files at a bit depth of 32 bits. Tuning was tested using two 2-second square wave tones generated with FabFilter One in Logic Pro X. Tone #1 was generated at a constant pitch of C4 +50ct. Tone #2 was generated at a pitch of C4 with the following settings: Modulation Generator (MG) Frequency set to 4.033 Hz,  MG waveform set to value 0.500, and Frequency Modulation MG set to value 0.123. Each tone was printed on a separate channel as a Bounce-in-place (bip). The two bips were then joined into a single, 6-second, mono .wav file with 2 seconds of silence between the bips. The 6-second .wav file was copied onto two new channels in Logic Pro X, and dragged out of Logic Pro onto the desktop for use in Melodyne standalone.

Audio was transferred into Melodyne: one mono channel in Logic Pro X was loaded with an instance of Melodyne non-ARA, one mono channel in Logic Pro X was loaded with an instance of Melodyne ARA, and the copy of the .wav file on the desktop was loaded into Melodyne standalone. All transfers were completed using the Melodic (Standard) algorithm. 

Transferred audio was quantized to pitch C4, offset 0 ct, Pitch Modulation 0.0%, Pitch Drift 0.0%. All other settings were left at defaults; Note Assignment mode was checked to verify that Playback Type in each case was 'Tonal'. 

Resulting audio was printed and imported into three new mono channels in Logic Pro X. Null testing was performed using the phase invert feature in Logic Pro X's stock 'Gain' plugin.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Just while it’s in my brain, for programmed “real-ish” drums I’ve been having good luck with drum samples + hihat and ride loops (Splice). 

Having a little sidechain action on the loops (keyed from whatever elements would be causing things to squish in compressed mics on real drums - usually the weight of the kick) can help the loops feel part of the kit. 

Stir in some faux ambience (Raum, SP2016, sometimes Ocean Way) and whatever bus processing you might do on a real kit helps with the smush.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve been thinking about @Joel "Roomie" Berghult‘s question re: mixing as you since he asked it. I think what Rauirí says about not knowing what we’re doing while we’re doing it is really true, so I’ve just been trying to dissect my process in my brain, away from the computer.  I think it comes down to 2 things for me. 

Here are my thoughts:


1) Choosing Sounds. 

In addition to vibe & genre & emotional intent, each instrument or sample that you pick covers a certain area of the overall picture. Knowing where that part is going to go in the overall arrangement changes how much hi end or low end or wetness (etc.) you want. It also steers performances. 

2) Actually Mixing As You Go 

Once a part is recorded, do a quick adjustment so that you hear closer to a finished product. This helps you make better choices about what else needs to be added, (or not added,) and will likely inspire the next step.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I know I’m the other matt but when I’m doing that technique I’m usually just working on a single cycle of the waveform. It’s tedious, but to me it’s totally transparent, and I’m rarely cross fading because it just doesn’t need it at that microscopic level. But I have no doubt that the better matt is right about it on bigger sections. 

When I do it in protools (the slightly larger sections) I’ve found you can nudge one of the two things you’re cross fading sample by sample and you’ll watch the over lapping waveforms kind of level out at a specific spot where it’s the most transparent sounding fade. 

A majority of time I find if you’ve cut up your blobs properly in melodyne, melodyne works just fine, but on the really really delicate shit I’ll do the single cycle wave form duplication. 

(I hope this makes sense, I’m hurtling through the air at 35000 feet on a not insignificant amount of Xanax)

author: Slow Hand
content:
Nope. I don't see why Ableton would be lacking in that way. It's perfectly capable of making great drums.

A pre-made drum loop will usually be more polished and ready-to-go than making your own drum pattern from individual samples. The pre-made loop will likely have been EQ'd, compressed, and mixed to work harmoniously, whereas if you're building a loop from scratch using samples it is up to you to polish and sculpt the sounds so that they work well together.

If the pre-made drum loop is like having someone serve you a finished meal, building the drum part from scratch means you have to learn to "cook" using those ingredients. It'll be harder to do well at first, but once you get the hang of it you'll be able to be more expressive.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If they're loops I always include the tempo in parentheses at the end of the file name *ex: Plaque perc loop 1 (130)*.

If they're one-shot drums I always prepend them with  *kick, snare, HH, OHH, etc* An example would be *kick Plaque 1*, *kick Plaque 2*, etc.

If it's a collection of all the sounds and loops from a finished song I create a folder for that song (with the tempo in the name) and within that folder are subfolders for *loops, drums, SFX, etc*

Finally, in addition to creating a folder with all of the assets for the songs (as I just mentioned), I copy all of the drum-hits to a single folder that has all of my custom *kicks, snares, HH, etc*. Same for any loops. This way I can search by song, but I can also go to a folder with *all* of my custom kick samples in one place.

author: Deleted User
content:
I feel you, especially in boom bap there's a lot that goes into that drunken swing feel. Same with tradition African groove. Easiest way is to load up a clip or loop from a drummer you like and extracting groove templates. You can quantize to the groove of your favorite drummer or a drum loop you dig. This will get you the results, but groove is a never ending journey of learning. Editing groove to make it feel the way you want to feel takes an understanding of what makes things groove one way or the other. It can be accents, dynamics, lengths of the notes, how much you deviate from the grid or what subdivisions you're on, and how the timing offsets rub and interact with each other in the whole instrumentation. Some drummers have really solid quintuplet swing, so instead of doing tripplet swing they'll play on the downbeat and the 3rd or 4th note of quintuplet. For this you can listen to guys like Nate Smith, he plays swings differently live than recordings- he drags and pushes the kicks and snares in recordings but for live, he only swings hats so there's more steady groove for other musicians to grab onto. 

On the other hand, for playing the grooves yourself- I find it helpful to dance and groove to the rhythms as much as I can to absorb the feel and internalize them. But in order to play ahead or behind with authority, you need to know where the grids are and metronome practice is crucial. I'm not that great at timing either, so I'm trying to do as much reps in with metronomes as I can. Learning to play on the grid is a first step before learning how to deviate with clear intention. I hope this helps!

author: spectrummasters
content: Logic Gang: quick share, Im finding the sample delay tool v useful in a few ways and reccommend for a few reasons. Picking up on the midi ticks convo last week, if youre programming in Logic , instead of dragging (and losing track of your moves) in the timeline/piano roll....throw one of these on an insert and increase the delay in tiny increments as you run down the track (typically hats and offbeat/ghost snares first) . You can quickly create the pocket youre looking for . Also added bonus...I believe under c. 12ms most people arent hearing a glaring time shift , (i dont go above 2ms ) so the delay is handy again just putting your hats , snares, percussive elements....just a millisecond or two behind/in front of each other so all your transient sounds are not hitting the 1/4,1/8, 16th counts at precisely the same instant. I find this helps with transients. Lastly, unlink the left and right on a stereo channel and youve got an instant width tool. Best for the transient and groove use tho imo.

author: spectrummasters
content:
yes agreed, production wise you can follow those roland drum kits pretty much through every decade to this day. its amazing to me that a number of todays budding producers can name these things partially, for example referring to the Roland 808 Kick Long and not know anything about the Roland 808, let alone the other modules. ......and parrallel to the "808 ", the 909 is still to this day, going strong in house with the likes of MK . From a production/mix viewpoint....i suppose these sounds themselves hit with such a charcter in the right frequencies that there must be something intrinsically appealing to us that will keep them forever relevant.Im diving back into the Linndrum Clap and the old Jermain Dupri / So So Def claps at the mo for a little diff sonic character .....they are all still in the same ilk as the rolands though. 

re: the drill hats.....thats another cyclical pattern there. In the uk thats been appearing and reforming for decades now. its a soca pattern that the uk appropriated into a period of uk garage production (about the same time that 2 step began to mutate into the hip-hop influenced So Solid style )......and then dipped into a scene we had follwing called UkFunky ( a mix of Us House and Carribean influenced drum patterns and bass) . Then it re-appeared again in those drill hats once the uk appropriated/re-mouldedd chicsago drill

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Great question. My feeling is that it comes back to not only labour, what you said, artistic vision. I think a lot of people will have a hard time believing a collection of unmodified splice loops made by someone else express any one artists’ artistic vision. 

I’m gonna take the temperature with some segments of my YouTube audience on this. I think it’s an interesting question.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
That last sentence of the first paragraph has weight imo. It also brings up a HUGE philosophy consideration that most musicians are uncomfortable wrestling with....


Craft vs Art.  You can be a music craftsman that has huge success and have never made personal artistic output. Art doesn't equal market value and market value doesn't rank art. 

Making with Splice can be rewarding and make a craft product of market value....  and it might even be transformative and unique enough to be art...  but it could just as easily be basic craft work without any intrinsic artistic value or personal expression.  It's a wide gradient of subjective value judgements.

*Keyscape* has some fantastic sounding (and unorthodox) sampled keyboard instruments. That said I'm not particularly fond of the sound of it's LA Custom C7 grand piano. Which is a little too hi-fi for my taste.

Lately I've been very impressed by NI's/Kontakt's *The Maverick* grand piano. I believe it's a vintage Bechstein grand. The sound is robust and rich without all of the "zing" that I see in a lot of full-scale sampled grand pianos. It sounds "woody" to me. I think it would make for a very nice jazz piano.

They did a really good job of sampling every facet it and it has enough flexibility that you can dial in the really intimate Nils Frahm-style damper/pedal/mechanical noises, which I like.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m probably an outlier in the usual drum pack consumer but I’ll give you my take:

1. I found when there’s a million samples I get uninterested quickly. I’d prefer 2 snare sounds as opposed to 15 slight variations of nearly the same thing.

2. I use an MPC, so the lower volume thing would be annoying for my personal use, but that’s an outlier.

3. You could farm out the Battery / Kontakt / etc packs to friends who would be willing to do it or use those tools a lot, that way you’re not stuck making a ton of them (unless you want to of course) 

4. I don’t touch loops usually but I know tons of others do. 

5. That’s it. Sounds like a super fun and badass project! You should document it on the way on the discord

Edit: I’m speaking to more electronic and supplemental use of drum samples. There are probably tons of folks out there who want all the options as if there was 100% a real drummer recorded in their studio.

author: Deleted User
content:
1) Different tunings, Having clean vs processed, peaking at below -6, good velocity layers, round robin is good but not really necessary for me, I personally don’t need all mics separate but would like to have a separate room sample and the mixed sample as well.

2) Yes please!! I hate it when samples peak at 0. I actually turn all of them down when I put them into a sampler to make it peak at -8 to -12

3) small snippets of hihats or snare ghost notes and some tom loops. I’d probably prefer them mixed only

4) for kits I think it is important. Round robin and velocity layers, and if you are doing rooms or separate mics having a kit makes an instantly playable and tweakable kit.

5) I’m not sure. Anything between 44.1/16 and 48/24 should be fine! Anything beyond might be too much

author: LAPhill
content:
Read the EULA of the samples, but in most cases, it's totally fine to use samples and loops as long as you're not selling them on their own. As in, if you use a hi-hat loop in your track, you can't have a section that is JUST the hi-hat loop. That would also apply to delivering stems. Your "percussion" stem, for instance, should have other elements baked in with it.

That doesn't apply in all cases and there are certain samples out there that don't allow for sync use. I can't remember which ones offhand, but that's why it's worth checking the license agreement.

I’m not sure if this’ll help, but I tend to go with whatever hits me at the time. If it’s a melody, I’ll sing it, mumble words, and allow the music to form around that idea. If it’s lyrics, then i grab a guitar or sit in front of the keyboard and play the accompaniment. Or if I’m in front of my computer, and melody line hits, I’ll play the melody, or chords and allow it to loop while I write. So I don’t necessarily balance, because to me that means I’m shutting part of my creativity off i order to allow the other part to flow, and more often than not, that kills the creative flow. 

So don’t try to balance anything. Whatever you feel, go with that and allow your creativity to flow.

author: LAPhill
content:
There are a couple ways to think about this - do you want maximally realistic results with less control over the actual notes, or do you want to make it sound as good as possible while still maintaining compositional ownership? I pretty much always fall into the latter.

As long as you have a decent library with enough round robins, short string lines are one of the easiest things to make sound good. I haven't used BBCSO, but I know it's light on variations in exchange for having a full set of orchestral instruments and articulations at a budget price. Any of Spitfire's main libraries would be fine, or Cinematic Studio Strings, Orchestral Tools.. pretty much anything should do the job as long as it has enough round robins and hopefully at least 4 dynamic layers.

author: Rollmottle
content: As others have said, recreating a beat you like is the school you need to go to. One of my favorite beats of all time is Fleetwood Mac's "Hypnotized" which is a swingy, triplet unchanging thing that is effectively a drum loop through the song, except Mick Fleetwood plays it. I recreated it using a sample pack of Mick Fleetwood's and turned it into a song after serious finagling, especially in the context of grid music. The insight into accent, velocity, swing, where in the grid things hit (or don't), which specific hits matter and how dropping just one or two key hits in a repetitive pattern can shift the groove entirely. It also tests your chops for figuring out choke groups, how to make closed and open hi hats sound "real" (if that's your goal) so on and so forth. I also love recreating a beat as a way in when musical inspiration may be lacking.

author: Slow Hand
content:
A few things:

1. What kind of samples are we talking about syncing here? Short samples like drums and loops? Or heavy sampled instruments like a piano/string library? Or both? 

2. I think the equivalent syncing feature in Dropbox would be "make available offline". If you right click a folder and "make available offline" it will continually update when it receives uploads from the other computer. Have you used that before? It doesn't have the lightning speed of a local network/ethernet connection, but if you can wait a few minutes it's good.

3. I assume these are Ableton sessions. Do you ever use the 'collect all and save' feature when saving sessions? It will gather every external sample (but not sampled instrument libraries) and save them to the project folder, which will save you the trouble of having to point your Ableton session to any external directory, because it will all be in the project folder. Very good when it comes to archiving sessions and opening them up years later.

author: austenballard
content:
There are two sides to that though

I am grateful that I only ever had to splice tape in school and that I don't need a six-seven figure analog studio and the Wrecking Crew to make a track

drag-and-drop samples, vocal comping, time stretching... these are things people who came before me spent days or weeks doing. VST synthesizers! Kontakt! 

we can do more, faster, because we don't have to muddle through every little thing. but this also means we have an obligation to learn how to combine the things that have become easy into new challenges and adventures

in 50ish years we went from Sgt Pepper to Skrillex because of this

it's the drive that humans who want to achieve and accomplish and push beyond possess

author: Maxim
content:
Sounds like you’re looking for density without it being cluttered or overproduced. 

Usually “noise” (not literally but parts of the groove that you mainly feel but don’t make out specifically like you would a kick and snare or hi hat) serves this purpose for me. Elements which if muted would leave you feeling like something is missing but you can’t necessarily make them out when in. 

I guess this could be anything from a few percussion loops (maybe panned/verb with no pre-delay or less high end to place them at the back of the mix) to a subtle vocal or foley sample playing one note throughout the groove. 

Layering to me is part of this but my intent with it is usually to create a sound or get more out of an element (like layering the attack of a snap with a clap for a different transient / texture). But this doesn’t always add to “fullness” in my mind. It just makes one element better or more interesting. 

Maybe start with the loops and foley. Splice Bridge makes testing things really easy too.

author: Deleted User
content:
the controller is called continuum. I believe it is an mpe (midi polyphonic expressions) device. I don’t know much about kyma but i would look into physical modeling because this is what the sound generation is based on. A lot of physical modeling is heavily based on delay lines, so I’d start there. Modal synthesis is also another cool concept where you would feed an impulse sample into a bank of parallel bandpass filters (very narrow q- which is also constructed with delay lines fundamentally). The idea is feedback and resonance from the filters would emulate acoustic modes. 

You can emulate this with fairly cheap stuff like leap motion, I’ve done a different project (something much simpler) with leap motion for gesture controlled music concrète. But you can definitely use the gestures to do the same thing with physical modeling. I’d be down to work on something together if you’re interested!

author: delwin
content:
I do this a lot!

In Ableton, you have soooo many options. Most often I put the sample on an Ableton Simpler and am able to slice / pitch / etc really fluidly — record that, and then edit by hand. This is my workflow for 90% of vocal chops. If it’s really simple I’ll do it by hand but I find I get more musical results if I can “play” the chop. 

There’s also Buffer Shuffler and Beat Repeat in Ableton which can be fun and unpredictable. 

The Glitch Machines plugins are also really nice if you’re going for something a bit crazy (two of them are free and very good). I don’t fully understand them yet so I just throw them on when I want something wacky to happen. 

And I’ll also second stutter edit — very fun for “playing” chops live too, and editing presets isn’t too hard either.

author: Slow Hand
content: Ah, thought of another one: Do the old sampler trick where you create an ultra-short, tuned, loop. So you'll get the transient smack up front and then the loop brackets ring out at a pitched tone from the ultra-fast repetitions.

author: Slow Hand
content:
It's really simple. It's basically creating a loop within a sampler and reducing the loop length to such a small window of time that the looped audio is perceived as a pitch. You "tune" it by adjusting the loop length shorter or longer.

I think the biggest issue is that vanilla samplers don't tend to give you very fine control unless they're built for sound design. Their loop length parameter will often go from 5 ms - 5000 ms, when what you really need is a loop in the 1 ms - 100 ms range.

So it might involve a custom-built device in *Reaktor* or something equivalent.

author: Deleted User
content:
All of these methods suggested will yield in different results. 

Resonators are made from delay using feedback to create tones. So you may need to resample to kill sustains - or not if you want it to have lengthiness. If you are going for SOPHIE kind of sound then you'd probably keep the feedback. 

Booms (filter resonance) are similar mechanisms but less tonal unless you turn up the feedback a lot more - it will certainly be more natural sounding as opposed to comb-filtery sound. 

Layering will give more focused pitch while maintaining the integrity of the layered sample sound, you would probably have the most control this way. 

Vocoder will have inherently baked sound because of the synthesis mechanism, it can be desirable or not depending on the scenario. 

With sampler looping, you will get grainier tail - dialing in the decay is necessary if you want the sound to be percussive because it will just continue sustaining. You can create pads this way too!

author: Deleted User
content:
Playing it or you can take a drum loop with groove you like and map out a groove template. Playing it is much faster and more feel, but often times it will need editing unless you have great timing. If it’s something loose then I’d definitely go ahead and move each notes because quantizing even 50% is going to change the feel. This is real nerdy but when there’s a really good moment in groove, I use logic’s event editor to look at how many ticks they are off by and snap other notes to somewhere near. For example, if I liked the feel of it being 40 ticks late then I’m gonna move everything (or some select notes that are in the same spot of the groove cycle) to somewhere nearby. Ticks are tempo relative so 50 ticks in 90bpm is different than 50 ticks in 120bpm. But it’s still in same relative timeline, but it’s going to feel different in different tempos. 

If you want it to groove like a drummer played it, best thing to do is play it in. You might end up quantizing or fixing velocity to al 127 later, but it’s going to be better than clicked in sequence if that is the style. Clicked in sequenced drums is its own groove too, you don’t want them having looseness so you quantize them all to 0 but you can still mess around with nudging them to be a bit behind or ahead of the grid.

author: JakeTB
content:
Method: Recorded vocal at 192kHz into Pro Tools. Exported via Shift+CMD+K at 192kHz and again at 48kHz. Vocals were both imported into Melodyne application in monophonic mode. Administered time stretching (both lengthened and shortened) via the time tool. Also administered pitch shifting via pitch tool and checked detection of tuning via correct pitch macro. After exporting these, they were reimported to see if detection had changed.

Objective Results:
-Upon import, vocal tempo detection was different. (One detected in 5/4, the other in 3/4, at drastically different tempos).
-For short notes, when using the time tool to stretch, there were audible differences in results.
-For long notes, when using the time tool to shorten, there was significantly less audible difference (subjectively: no difference)
-For pitch detection, the algorithm detected pitch differently both audibly and visually.

Subjective Opinions:
-Time stretching yielded reduced artifacts in extreme settings when done at 192kHz. It did not eliminate all artifacts, but did reduce them.
-When time stretching in a more nuanced way, the differences in artifacts were negligible.
-When adjusting pitch manually, there was no audible difference in the quality of the pitch shifting at different sample rates. (For this test, everything was shifted up half an octave before any adjustments made)
-When detecting pitch, both behaved quite differently. This was partially due to detection of select blobs being different at either sample rate. (This was most surprising to me of all the results)
-When blobs were adjusted to match as closely as possible by hand, the tuning seemed to behave identically, including locations and levels of artifacts. (My gut says they “felt” different but that is most likely either placebo or the slight differences in true blob locations)

author: austenballard
content:
Generated 2x 5-second sine waves at 110 Hz; one at 48k32, the other at 96k32

Imported each sine wave into Melodyne, set to matching sample rate, and pitched down by 1 octave

Observed the resulting pitched-down sine waves for evidence of aliasing with Voxengo SPAN

author: Ross Fortune
content:
1) what are the top 5 most important things for you in purchasing a drum sample pack ?


I never purchase drum sample packs - not since having Splice. I do like a clear identity in a pack though - for instance, The Kount's sample pack has all those lo-fi/saturated kicks and snares, wonky grooves and crusty hi hats etc that sit very much in his genre, so if I'm reaching for that sound, I know exactly where to go. 

I don't know your drummer or his band, but I'd wonder what distinctive character you could capture in your pack? So that I know exactly where to go when I want "that" sound in a writing session instant. 


2) I’m always annoyed that all samples are 0.0db normalized and I always have to turned them way down to keep my gain staging coherent, would I be crazy to have them peak at -8 ? Would people automatically hate it ? 

I produce largely in Ableton now, and when you drop a sample in the drum rack, the instance of Simpler it creates defaults to -12dB. With the velocity:volume dial at default (45%), this causes a 0dB sample to play back at -6dB when velocity=100 (the default). My template has all mixer faders (including a basic drum rack + instance of Drum Buss) trimmed to -9dB (similar to my mix gain staging strategy I detailed previously), allowing me to mash stuff up if needed, and still have headroom to not have to max out vocals when it comes to cutting them. What I'm saying in a roundabout way is... I've already made allowances for 0dB samples, so I don't care - but you probably should, because if you're selling on Splice, they could sound dwarfed against the next pack.

author: Skyler Young
content: The tone shift effect is something that I was thinking about for a long time - it manipulates which samples you access for each note played. For example you shift it +12 and play C1 it will take the sample from C0 and play it at double speed - changing the character of the sound sometimes drastically. If the range knob is at 50% and shift is at 0 and you play C0 it will use the sample from G0 (because it’s 50% the distance from C0) and if you play C2 it will use the sample from G1 - also has interesting effects on the sound. I still haven’t figured out the best way of explaining this function but I find it really usable and I’ve never seen sometime implement it before.

author: Slow Hand
content:
@Skyler Young This looks cool. A neat feature I'd love to see someday would be to add a simple EQ device and allow internal resampling of one-shot samples. The idea is that samples often have some boxiness or ringing that needs to be EQ'd out, but those problem-zones shift when the sample is transposed up and down, making any post-sampler EQ moves ineffectual.

If you could streamline the process of re-recording a static sample with the necessary EQ cuts committed into the one-shot then those cuts would be transposed along with the sample when you play it up and down the keyboard.

author: Slow Hand
content:
@Josh I owned an NI Maschine+ (the standalone hardware unit) for a year before I eventually sold it. My reasons were much like yours; to get away from software and have a standalone instrument to play with.

I don't have many bad things to say about it, but ultimately it just wasn't a good fit for the way my brain works. NI have crammed a tremendous amount of features and functions into that thing. Most of which it does very well, but when it came time to do sequencing in the unit the interface was just too much of a hurdle for me. I found it hard to keep all of the key commands in my head to do simple commands. I think it's a little *too* efficient in how many options they've fit into it. Remembering the commands among it's unorthodox button layout was challenging and unintuitive for me.

As you might imagine, it integrates perfectly with the Maschine software, which is basically a DAW within a plugin that controls the hardware and vice-versa if you choose to use a computer. But I wasn't interested in that, because I can achieve the same things and more with plain old Ableton.

It *does* have a fantastic sample library and the NI sample packs you can purchase are very well done.

author: LAPhill
content:
MTC and MMC are likely your best bets. But MIDI is not sample accurate, so you can expect some milliseconds of drift at least, different each time you hit play. Might be fine for coming up with parts, but it’s not a great solution for a whole project. 

The only tech I’ve seen that gets around that is Avid’s Satellite Link, but that’s just for syncing Pro Tools rigs.

author: sethearnest
content: Had the original sample you used been manipulated overall pitch- or timing-wise by you at all?

author: sethearnest
content:
You might already be doing this, and might be the way everyone else has always done it, but a light bulb moment for me when I've re-created samples: I needed to match the *original* sample's tempo and pitch, instruments, feel, etc etc, get it sounding like the original sample fully at it's original everything, *then* manipulate as a "sample" the same way I did the original manipulation. Helps it feel more like the sample. 

Seemed especially important with any pitching happening -- something about the whole being pitched was different than trying to match the already-pitched-down version.

author: Ross Fortune
content: That’s great, thank you for jogging the memory. Weirdly I’ve done so many vocal sample replays in the last year, and this is exactly how I’d approach it. Can’t believe I didn’t think to start there 🤦🏻‍♂️

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I'm asking if you want samples of solo string instruments or a string section.

For ensemble I've been enjoying the *NI Session Strings 2*. I've also got the *Spitfire BBC Symphony* but I'm less fond of those because they're recorded from an orchestral perspective and have a lot of room sound baked in, whereas *Session Strings 2* have a closer perspective. If you want an ensemble sound plus some major grit and close-miking I *do* like the *Bernard Hermann* orchestral library from Spitfire.

For solo strings the *NI Cremona Quartet* instruments are really, really nice. They're a pleasure to play with and sound fantastic. These have maximum presence too, so you can get some very direct sounds with them. I'm really enjoying them. The articulation and tonal options are extremely thorough.

A while back a few people recommended *Sunset Strings* by Realitone. While I haven't used it yet, they look very promising. They seem to be serving people who want a rock/pop string feel, which could be just the ticket.

author: Maxim
content: To make things a bit bigger, Shopify makes almost 3 billion in revenue every year, yet the companies built on top of Shopify make close to 200 billion combined. The company that makes 100 million a year using Shopify doesn't pay that much more than the company that only makes 100k a year. What I mean by that, Oliver created a sample pack that thousands of people can use the way they want to. Why should they by default get credit when someone comes along and builds something that's widely successful with that? Didn't everyone win? (Of course it's not the same but I'm trying to get to the source which is I think what we believe to be artistic integrity).

author: Zack Hames
content:
So, I think it’s superbly underrated. Especially the new Akai MPC lives, one, etc series.

I use it as a drum machine/sampler/sequencer for all of my hardware synths. It’s the brain and controller for everything.

But you can also use it completely on its own, you can put any sample all the way across a keyboard/pads to the correct pitch automatically. 

There are built in AIR effects. You can time stretch, etc do whatever with samples. 

Load up any drum samples and go to town. 

It also has some built in instruments / synths, but I rarely use those. 

It’s essentially a portable DAW as far as music production. I prefer it to computer by far for producing / writing with samples and synths

author: vostral
content:
Here are two samples including a static loop and a groovy loop.
- On the static loop, I use DX drum machine HiHat and just barely put them 1/8 on the grid

- On the programmed loop, I adjust the gain up & down for each hat piece, fade in/out to get varied length, time adjusting, and finally a Tremolo.

author: aliberger
content: snd is the mpc's native format for saving sounds, once you get the wavs loaded into memory i believe they can be saved as snd files. pgm files are programs (data like which sample is assigned to which pad and all the parameters around that) which you create on the mpc. programs don't contain any sound data themselves, they reference the sounds by filename

author: spectrummasters
content: So , you can do computer wavs ->mpc .snd via digital transfer (floppy / flash card or spdif) but you’re circumventing perhaps the best part of the mpc (the sampler ) and gonna run into file naming and format problems

author: Zack Hames
content:
I don't give a major fuck about being able to tweak the sounds other than pitch within a sampler. (don't need effects or EQ built in necessarily but it can be nice)
I do like using battery for key-tracking samples. but again, it still loads everything as a fucking loop by default. I just read the *entire* manual, there is 0 way to change the default way it loads in.

author: Zack Hames
content:
here's the workflow:

I don't use many of the preset kits anymore. Just not really the sounds I'm looking for. I have a massive library of samples that i like to use. Accessing those is easy.
The problem is I don't make preset kits. Every session, every kit, is a different combination of things, always starting fresh. So I am in the Library view constantly going through samples/files to load into any Cell of Battery.

When I find a sound I like, I can click it or drag it to the cell I want. This is all great.

But, the second i drop it in, I have to change the velocity from 0-100% (I saved my default preset to have all cells at 0% velocity which seems to be working). and then *every time i add a new sample or replace a sample* it makes it a loop in the "Editor" window. There is no shortcut, no preference, no saving a preset, that allows me to essentially remove that behavior.

author: Zack Hames
content: which just shows you how to make every individual cell not a loop. but the second you drop a new file in, boom, loop activated.

author: spectrummasters
content:
One of the most helpful things to break out of the 4/8 bar loop of death is to begin your project with the audio file of a track you love the arrangement for imported . 

Mute it and set your project to its tempo (it’s just easier ) 

Now get to jamming away 

Once you’ve built the loop you adore , 
Mute it 

Listen again from top to bottom the track you love the arrangements for . 

Listen to how the different elements come in and out , where , how . 

How are the motifs evolved . Any counter melody / rythms .

Drops and breakdowns 

Make notes of it all . 
Then copy it exactly or to the degree you want with your own elements of your loop . 

Voila . You made a fully arranged track . 

Repeat

author: Slow Hand
content:
Maybe it's just my taste, but if I'm sequencing sampled instruments I'm not trying to sample guitars and I don't think we need another drum library, either. Drums and percussion already translate well to sampling (for the most part). 

I want strings and woodwinds, or brass. Gimme some of that, and make it something with some real energy and excitement. Their platform seems capable of expressing things that traditional sampled instruments cannot do, so lean into those strengths and make the parts a little more opinionated. A little more unique.
